Name: chuan bei mu
Pharmaceutical: Chuan bei mu: Bulbus Fritillariae Cirrhosae
Zhe bei mu: Bulbus Fritillariae Thunbergii
Biological: Fritillaria cirrhosa D. Don (chuan bei mu)
F. unibracteata Hsiao et K. C. Hsiao (chuan bei mu)
Fritillaria verticillata Willd. var. Fritillaria thunbergii Bak.(zhe bei mu)
Other name: Prescription names for chuan bei mu: chuan bei 川貝, jian bei mu 尖貝母
Prescription names for zhe bei mu: zhe bei 浙貝, xiang bei 象貝, da bei mu 大貝母

Geography: Chuan bei mu (Bulbus Fritillariae Cirrhosae): Sichuan, Yunnan, Xizang.
Zhe bei mu (Bulbus Fritillariae Thunbergii): Zhejiang, Jiangsu, Anhui, Hunan.
Properties: Chuan bei mu: mildly cold; sweet; bitter.
Maladies Treated: Hot cough due to yinxu with thick phlegm.
陰虛咳嗽痰稠 (yinxu cough with thick phlegm).
Chuan bei mu: chronic cough that injured yin (into yinxu), dry cough without phlegm; lung dryness cough.
Zhe bei mu: stagnant phlegm with cough; cough with yellow phlegm; clears lung and disperses nodules.
Medical Function: Clears lung heat and rids of phlegm; moistens the Lung and disperses nodules; stops cough and transforms phlegm (潤肺散結，止咳化痰).
Chuan bei mu is mildly cold and moisturizing: for lung dryness cough and prolonged cough injuring yin, dry cough without phlegm.
Zhe bei mu is colder than chuan bei mu; stronger purging to get rid of stagnant phlegm and stop cough; suitable for cough with yellow phlegm.
Small amount of the saponin can raise blood pressure of dogs, cats, and rabbits while large amount can lower it.
Injection of 7.5 ml/kg peimine to rabbits increased blood sugar and it was able to maintain it for more than 2 hours [3].
Dosage: For decoction: 3 to 10 g. As powder form (mixed in water): 1 to 2 g.
Samples of Formulae: dang gui bei mu ku shen wan (當歸貝母苦參丸); jie geng bai san (桔梗白散); yang fei tang (養肺湯).
Contraindications: Not to use by those with pixu (spleen deficient), cold, with wet phlegm and cold cough. Also not to use she dan chuan bei mo, chen pi chuan bei mo, chuan bei mu, fu fang she dan chuan bei mo. Raw bei mu is toxic and not for internal use.
Research:
Small amount of the saponin can raise blood pressure of dogs, cats, and rabbits while large amount can lower it.
Injection of 7.5 ml/kg peimine to rabbits, increased blood sugar and it was able to maintain it for more than 2 hours [3].
Antibiotic effect.
Notes:
Chuan bei mu (川貝母) is characterized as mildly cold with a moisturizing quality; it is emphasized for lung dryness patterns, prolonged cough that injures yin, and dry cough without phlegm.
Zhe bei mu (浙貝母) is colder than chuan bei mu, with stronger opening/purging to eliminate phlegm; indicated for clearing the Lung, dispersing nodules, and cough with yellow phlegm.

Name: chuan xiong
Biological: Cnidium officinale Makino (ri ben chuan xiong 日本川芎)

Medical Function: dilates coronary arteries, improves blood flow to heart muscles, lower oxygen consumption of heart muscles
improves blood flow to the the brain and limbs, lower resistant of the peripheral blood vessels
helps resist effect of lack of vitamin E
inhibits the activity of tyrosinase, thus helps to eliminate age spots (brown spots) and spreckles

Name: jia zhu tao
Other name: hong hua jia zhu tao 紅花夾竹桃

Geography: Cultivated in most parts of China (中國各省區均有栽培).
Maladies Treated: swelling and pain from impact injuries
Medical Function: Its saponins may be a good potential for use as cardiac stimulant.
Antiviral activities against influenza virus (RNA) and HSV (DNA).
強心利尿: strengthens the Heart and promotes diuresis.
祛痰定喘: transforms phlegm and calms wheezing.
散瘀止痛: disperses stasis to stop pain.

In Ayurvedic medicine, the roots are being used as aphrodisiac, tonic and for chronic pain in abdomen and in joints. The flowers are also being used as aphrodisiac and for lumbago, inflammations, headache and scabies. (Do not use if you are not trained in this herb)
Dosage: In decoction for oral consumption: 0.3 to 0.9 g. In powder form: 0.15 g to 0.3 g.
Contraindications:
Very toxic herb. Whole plant is toxic; smoke from burning the plant is highly toxic.
Not to use during pregnancy.
Large dosages and/or long-term usage can be toxic to kidneys.
Overdose can cause serious arrhythmia, hypotension, and coma.
Do not use if you are not trained in this herb.
Research: S.A.A. Jassim and M.A. Naji: exhibited considerable antiviral activities against influenza virus (RNA) and HSV (DNA) (Rajbhandari et al. 2001).
Notes:
Symptoms and Treatment: See this site for symptoms of toxicity and treatment information.

Geography: Throughout central, eastern, and southern China, especially Guangdong and Jiangsu provinces.
Maladies Treated: Nausea, vomiting, hiccups, belching due to stomach heat
Medical Function: Transforms phlegm; clears lung heat; descends Lung qi; calms the Lungs
Harmonizes the Stomach; clears Stomach heat; calms the Stomach
Protects liver; anti-hepatitis: rapidly lowers ALT and AST, resolves jaundice, improves appetite, inhibits fibrosis, restores liver function (ursolic acid)
Dosage: Dry leaves: 4.5–12 g; fresh leaves: 15–30 g (daily dosage).
Contraindications: Do not use for cough due to externally contracted cold wind in the Lung or for vomiting due to Stomach cold. Ursolic acid (an active ingredient) has a certain degree of toxicity to sperm.
Research:
The ursolic acid is one of the chemicals of triterpene exist in natural plants. It possesses the effects of sedation, anti-inflammatory, anti-biotic, inhibiting blood sugar, anti-ulcers, lowering blood sugar, and anti-oxidation. Protects liver, anti-hepatitis: ursolic acid can rapidly lower ALT, AST, rid of jaundice, improve appetite, inhibit the forming of fibrosis, and recover the function of the liver. It has the characteristics of getting the healing result fast, shortening of the therapy period, and with stable result. Ursolic acid is a triterpenoid compound present in natural plants, possessing sedation, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, anti-diabetes, anti-ulcer, lowering blood sugar, and other biological effects; ursolic acid also has an obvious antioxidant function.

1 Hepatoprotective, anti-hepatitis action: Clinically, ursolic acid shows significant and rapid lowering of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and serum transaminases, resolution of jaundice, increased appetite, anti-fibrosis, and restoration of liver function; it has characteristics of quick effect, short course, and stable results. Saraswat et al. (India) found that ursolic acid (5–20 mg/kg) has a protective effect against CC1-induced hepatotoxicity in rats (animal experiment). Pretreatment with ursolic acid significantly increased the survival rate of rat hepatocytes, and in experiments ursolic acid was observed to have an anti-cholestatic effect, with increases in bile flow and its contents. From the mechanism of action of CC1, it is inferred that the therapeutic mechanism of ursolic acid on damaged hepatocytes may be similar to its isomer oleanolic acid, in protecting and stabilizing the biomembrane systems of hepatocyte membranes and organelles, restoring changes in permeability and active transport functions to normal, thereby restoring the movement and distribution of ions and water inside and outside cells; regenerative capacity is restored in succession, promoting repair of necrotic hepatocytes in the central zone of hepatic lobules. The project “Research and development of a new class I anti-hepatitis traditional Chinese medicine drug ursolic acid and its preparations” achieved major progress, was included in the 2002 National “863” Program, received national scientific research funding of 1 million yuan, and became a national-level major research topic (2002AA2Z3217).

2 Anti-tumor action: Ursolic acid has resistance against multiple carcinogens and tumor promoters. Research found that ursolic acid can significantly inhibit proliferation of HL-60 cells and induce their apoptosis; it can significantly increase the phagocytic function of mouse macrophages (animal experiment); it can inhibit proliferation of the human tongue squamous carcinoma cell line TSCCa, with a half-maximal inhibitory concentration for growth of about 12.5 μmol·L−1, showing a definite dose–effect relationship within 24 h; in situ hybridization showed that the inhibitory effect of ursolic acid on TSCCa cells is related to inhibition of the in situ expression of nuclear transcription factors. In vivo experiments proved that ursolic acid can significantly enhance the body’s immune function (animal experiment), indicating that the anti-tumor effect of ursolic acid is broad and that ursolic acid is very likely to become a low-toxicity, effective new anti-cancer drug. Ursolic acid has preventive and inhibitory effects at various stages of tumor formation and growth, inhibiting tumor formation and growth and inducing differentiation of cancer cells. Li J et al. demonstrated through experiments and clinical trials that ursolic acid can resist DNA mutations, inhibit initiation of carcinogenesis, and counteract carcinogens such as benzo[a]pyrene and aflatoxin B1 in inducing gene mutations. In an early antigen (EBV-EA) activation assay used to screen inhibitors of tumor promoters for skin cancer, Wang Peng found that ursolic acid has an inhibitory effect on TPA-induced EBV-EA activation in Raji cells almost the same as retinoic acid, and it results in higher survival of Raji cells; using the isotopically labeled phorbol ester compound 3H-PDB2, it was demonstrated that ursolic acid does not affect the binding of TPA to its receptor, i.e., it does not act by competing for the TPA site, but effectively blocks the downstream steps after the carcinogen binds to the receptor. Guevara et al. showed that ursolic acid can reduce by 76% the number of micronucleated polychromatic erythrocytes caused by mutagens. Ohigachi et al. showed that ursolic acid has an inhibitory effect on phorbol ester (TPA)-induced Raji cell EBA–EA activation, to a degree almost the same as retinoic acid; the survival rate of Raji cells was higher than the retinoic-acid-treated group; the mechanism is to effectively block downstream steps after TPA binds to its receptor. H...ng et al. found that ursolic acid significantly inhibits the tumor-promoting effect of TPA on DMBA-induced mouse skin cancer (animal experiment); the mechanism is that TPA can induce increased activity of epidermal ornithine decarboxylase (ODC), and ursolic acid can inhibit this step, thereby causing polyamine depletion, growth inhibition, accumulation of cells at an early stage, and differentiation.

3 Antioxidant: Ursolic acid is a relatively strong antioxidant. Experiments show that ursolic acid can inhibit 5-lipoxygenase and cyclooxygenase activity in the metabolism of arachidonic acid, preventing the formation of prostaglandins and leukotrienes; this may be the reason for ursolic acid’s inhibition of inflammatory responses and lipid peroxidation. Subbaramaiah et al. showed that ursolic acid can inhibit transcription of cyclooxygenase in human mammary epithelial cells, thereby also inhibiting prostaglandin formation. The antioxidant effect of ursolic acid has positive effects on anti-aging, removing skin spots, and depigmentation. Among 29 Japanese patents related to ursolic acid from 1983 to 2004, 10 concern the application of ursolic acid in skin beauty and health; as a cosmetic, ursolic acid is stable, with color and odor unchanged over time, and has a very good tactile feel, thus having wide application in skin care products.

4 Antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral: Using the acetic acid writhing test and hot plate test, Tapondjou et al. confirmed that ursolic acid and hydroxyursolic acid have similar anti-inflammatory and antibacterial effects. Ursolic acid can respectively inhibit production of superoxide induced by fMLP and by arachidonic acid. When ursolic acid and fMLP were added to cell culture medium, ursolic acid dose-dependently inhibited the 45 kDa protein tyrosine phosphorylation induced by fMLP. Ursolic acid also has trypanocidal activity; after incubation for 2 h at a concentration of 2 g·L−1, the motility of Trypanosoma cruzi flagellates was completely inhibited. Ursolic acid can lead to decreased cell viability. Wang Peng demonstrated that genomic DNA fragmentation induced by ursolic acid indicates that its mechanism of inducing cell death is apoptosis; ursolic acid can inhibit proliferation of human acute promyelocytic leukemia cells (HL-60), with an IC50 of 8.26 μM, and can induce concomitant apoptosis.

5 Effects of lowering blood lipids, anti-atherosclerosis, and lowering blood sugar: Ursolic acid can reduce blood cholesterol (44%) and β-lipoprotein levels (50%) in rabbits and rats (animal experiments), showing lipid-lowering and anti-atherosclerotic effects. Ursolic acid can improve symptoms caused by dyslipidemia, such as liver–kidney yin deficiency, tinnitus, dry mouth, reduced sleep, irritability, limb numbness with fear of cold, and constipation; the total effective rate for lipid lowering was 95%.

6 Inhibition of AIDS virus: The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is the causative agent of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Tian Ying et al., through clinical trials, proved that ursolic acid has a strong inhibitory effect on HIV-1 protease activity, with a 50% inhibitory concentration (IC50) of 8 μmol/L. HIV-1 protease is a homodimeric enzyme; ursolic acid may inhibit the dimerization of HIV-1 protease to inhibit its activity, thereby inhibiting the function of HIV protease. Ursolic acid and its malonic acid derivative can inhibit HIV-1 protease, with IC50 values of 8 and 6 μmol/L, respectively.

7 Anti-diabetes: (heading noted; details not provided in the source segment).

Agropyrum repens P. Beauv. (ou mao gen 歐 茅 根 )

Medical Function: cools the blood and stops bleeding
clears heat from stomach and lungs
promotes urination, especially during 5~10 days while taking the herb. It can be due to the potassium salt in the herb.
Dosage: 9 to 24 g. Using by itself, up to 60 g.
Samples of Formulae:
For hemorrhagic fever:
Formula 1: Composition: Bai Mao Gen (Rhizome of wooly grass), Da Huang (Rhubarb), Mang Xiao (Mirabilite / Glauber's salt), Zhi Shi (Immature bitter orange), Tao Ren (Peach kernel), Sheng Di Huang (Raw rehmannia root), Mai Dong (Ophiopogon tuber), Mu Tong (Akebia stem).

Formula 2: Composition: Bai Mao Gen (Rhizome of wooly grass) 150 g, Dan Shen (Salvia miltiorrhiza root) 20 g, Lu Gen (Reed rhizome) 30 g, Huang Bai (Phellodendron bark) 10 g, Pei Lan (Eupatorium) 15 g, Dan Pi (Moutan cortex) 10 g. Adjust the formula according to the syndrome.

For Cancer of the digestive track: Composition: Bai Mao Gen (Rhizome of wooly grass) 10 g, Bai Hua She She Cao (Hedyotis diffusa) 12 g, Ban Zhi Lian (Scutellaria barbata) 10 g. Boil with water. Use as tea.

For periodontitis: click here for formula.
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of pixu (spleen deficient) or shenyangxu (kidney yang deficient) conditions. Use care if blood pressure is low because of its diuretic effect.
